question: If science recognizes the human-animal continuum and the connectedness of all of life, which of the following would not align with this view according to Claude Lévi-Strauss?

answers.text: Many Indigenous groups equate the “other,” or those who are not members of their tribe, as animals.
Cultures and religions view humans as separate from nature.
A religion such as Buddhism believes in the connectedness of all life. This is further expressed in the belief that animals and humans can reincarnate into either form.
In the Andes, some Indigenous groups separate humans from the “other” based on their ability to speak their language.
